bibl.title: Letter with memorandum from William Crawford Gorgas to Charles A.L. Reed, February 17, 1905

div1.p: Gorgas writes to Reed concerning the organization of the Canal Zone Sanitary Department, and details problems in its function. Memorandum details the problems in the Panama Canal.

div1.head: Letter with memorandum from William Crawford Gorgas to Charles A.L. Reed, February 17, 1905
div1.opener:
Memorandum
of Col WC Gorgas
Ch. San. Officer
Ancon, Isthmian Canal Zone,
February 17, 1905.
Dr. Reed
(Dr. C.A.L. Reed of Cincinnati)
Dear Doctor:-
div1.p:
I have just read the recommendations of the Secretary
of War before the Senate Committee, and this gives me a pretty good
idea of the character of general organization the Secretary would
like to have in Panamá.

As I understand the Secretary's scheme, it is: that
Congress authorize the President to construct the canal, through
the Commission,- as a body or individually as he thinks best.
That the construction of the canal be placed under the Secretary
of War; that an Executive body of three be established on the
Isthmus, to consist of the Chief Engineer, the Governor and one
other member; that the rest of the Commission be merely advisory.
This, for the execution of sanitary work, I can see would be a
great improvement over the present arrangement. But my idea would
be under this organization, that the Chief Sanitary Officer report
directly to the Secretary of War as the highest authority. The
Sanitary Department would have no representation on this governing
body; and while the Chief Sanitary Officer would be in contact with
them and would be able to urge his views personally, there would
still be many objections to this form of organization, of much the
2
the same character as exist under the present Commission. That
there would be no one on this board who had any special knowledge
of sanitary matters. But where the Sanitary Officer reported di-
rectly to this board or to the Secretary, I think the other points
named in the memoranda just given you, are equally important. If
the Sanitary Officer reports to this body he should not do so as a
subordinate to the Governor or any other department, but directly,
as do now the Chief Engineer, the Chief of Material & Supplies and
the Disbursing Officer. The department should have its own chief
of material & supplies, who should report direct to the Chief Sani-
tary Officer and be under his orders; should have its own construct-
ing officer, who should also report direct to the Chief Sanitary
Officer and be under his control; and should have its own disburs-
ing officer, who should bear the same relation to the Chief Sanitary
Officer as the others.

The whole object of the organization is to enable the
Sanitary Department rapidly to organize, to get its supplies prompt-
ly, to get its constructing done promptly and to have its payments
made promptly. The experience of the past nine months shows that
this could not be accomplished under the present organization, no
matter what efforts and pressure were brought to bear; and it seems
to me that there will always be this difficulty as long as the Sani-
tary Department has to have the details of its work carried on
through the other departments. The wants of the Sanitary Depart-
ment are small as compared with the great work going on. It is
natural that an ounce of quinine is not very important in the eyes
of the Chief of Material & Supplies, as compared with a steam dredge;
and the ounce of quinine will be overlooked and the steam dredge
3
attended to if the work is pressing. And this will be the case all
through. If the Sanitary Department has to depend for its executive
work upon the other departments, I believe this executive work will
always be slow and done under great difficulties. This was our
experience in Cuba after over two years of trial; and we finally
adopted a general plan, as described above, as the only means of
getting our work done effectively.

div1.head: MEMORANDUM FOR DR REED.
div1.p:
Certain serious defects in the Sanitary Organization at present are
due to the fact that the Commission originally adopted no general plan covering
the whole ground. I proposed to them an organization, which, in my opinion,
covered the whole ground in April, 1904: my idea under this plan being to get the
department thoroughly organized in, any half a year, and within a year from that
time, eighteen months from the date of my appointment, to have the towns of
Panama and Colon and the strip between them in a good sanitary condition in every
respect. This scheme was considered at their meeting May 8th, 1904, and action
was taken as shown by the within quotation, found on page 44. Proceedings, Isthmian
Canal Commission, March to September, 1904.

“The Chairman submitted a report on the sanitation of the Canal
Zone and Panama and Colon by Drs. Gorgas, Ross and LaGarde, accompanied by
a report to Dr Gorgas by Captain Gillette, of the Engineer Corps, U. S. A.,
relating to the condition of hospital buildings and kindred matters.

The general outline for a scheme of sanitation for the Canal
Zone, submitted by Colonel W. C. Gorgas, U.S.A.; Medical Director, John W.
Ross, U.S.N., and Major Louis A. LaGarde, U.S.A.; was considered and the follow-
ing action was taken:

The Chief Sanitary Officer and the Director of Hospitals, in
addition to other duties, were designated as the Health Board for Colon and
Panama, as well as of the Canal Zone, in lieu of the independent health boards
provided for in the scheme of sanitation.

The Chief Sanitary Officer was authorized to proceed with the
cleaning, disinfecting and collecting of garbage and nightsoil in Colon and
Panama, and to employ staffs for these purposes as may be necessary from time
to time, whose wages are to be fixed by the Commission before employment; to
make requisition for carts, mules, garbage cans, and so forth, as needed. He
was authorized to have plans prepared for a 100-bed hospital, and to employ
a physician to take charge of the Colon Hospital and act as sanitary officer,
at a salary of $250. per month, if taken from civil life, and to employ what
other staff may be necessary from time to time, whose rates of pay will be
fixed by the Commission before employment.

The matter of quarantine stations at Colon and Panama was referred
back to Colonel Gorgas for further consideration and recommendation.

The employment of a sanitary officer for the Canal Zone, from Colon
to Panama, at a salary not exceeding $350. per month if taken from civil life,
one clerk at $125. per month, two clerks at $100. per month, two sanitary
officers at $100. per month, and other sanitary officers at $50. per month was
authorized, such employment to begin from time to time as needed.

A pathologist and clinician for the General Hospital at Ancon Hill
at a salary of $333.33 per month was authorized. Also other staff for this
hospital as needed from time to time, their pay to be fixed by the Commission
before employment.
- 2 -
Staffs for Director of Hospital and Chief Sanitary Officer were also
authorized, to be employed as needed from time to time, their salaries
to be fixed by the Commission before employment.

The wages of foremen, laborers and other subordinates of like
class employed from time to time as needed and not fixed by the
Commission, shall be temporarily fixed by the representative of the
Commission on the Isthmus.

Action on the matter of taking charge of the City Hospital
and Poor House in Panama, Convalescent Hospital at Taboga Island and
immigration stations in Panama and Colon was deferred

It was decided that all disbursements should be made through the
Disbursing Officer of the Commission, and all purchases should be made by the
Purchasing Agent of the Commission, and independent disbursing officer and
purchasing agent were not allowed.”

This shows what a very limited Sanitary Department was at that time
contemplated by the Commission.

At the direction of the Commission, after I had been on the Isthmus
about six weeks and started such organization as had so far been authorized,
I again submitted a scheme upon which they noted at their meeting of August 28th.
Proceedings will be found on Page 159.

This scheme adopted by them was excellent in many respects and liberal
as far as appropriation went, but it left out very important matters, such as
the disposal of nightsoil along the Zone and making no provision for the health
departments of Panama and Colon and many minor details. But the greatest defect
in the organization has been that, we have been entirely unable to carry out many
of the provisions made in this scheme. The Supply Department not having been
entirely organized, we have been unable to get a great part of our supplies through
them. None of the large requisitions made back in July, August and September
have not yet been filled, and the same has been the case in regard to
construction and repair. We had to do this through another department. Repairs
and construction asked for in July remain still unfinished. I think the fact
that so incomplete a scheme was adopted in the beginning was due a good deal to
the personnel of the Commission. None of the gentlemen deciding this matter
had any special sanitary or medical knowledge. It is true that I had a good
opportunity of presenting my views and arguments beforehand, but, beyond this
-3-
sanitation had no representation in their counsels.

After the scheme had been adopted I was removed still further from them,
having to communicate with them subject to the control of the Board of Health and
through the Governor. At present I am merely sanitary adviser of the Governor,
he making recommendation on sanitary matters to the Commission.

With regard to the difficulty in getting supplies and construction
work done, I think they are inherit in the organization, and I do not believe
the work can ever be carried out promptly under the present plan. I stated this
to the Commission at the time of their adoption, pointing out that from my past
experience in these matters, I believe supplies for our department could not
be obtained in this way, that construction could not be done in this way,
that I would necessarily be hold back until these departments were organized and
that other interests would be so great that the smaller demands of my department
in these respects would be overlooked. This has been the case to an eminent
degree.

The functions of the Sanitary Department here are peculiar. Our
reason d' etre is to aid in the construction of the Canal. In this respect we
principally come in contact with the laborers of the Engineer Department and
probably have more extensive and intimate relations with the Chief of Engineers
than with any other official.

As to having charge of the health of the towns of Panama and Colon, we
derive our authority exclusively from the Panamaian Government, and as far as
authority goes in this respect we are entirely outside of the jurisdiction
of the Commission. Along the Zone and as far as any sanitary control of the
villages is concerned, we come in contact with the Zone Government. I think,
therefore, the Chief Sanitary Officer should report directly to the supreme authority,
as do the Chief of Engineers, Chief of Material and Supplies and the Paymaster.

At present we are subordinate, having no direct contact with the Chief
Engineer or with the Commission.

The schemes I formerly submitted to the Commission in April and
September were based upon the organization under similar circumstances, which
were slowly evolved at Havana, after three years experience, in almost exactly
similar work, and this in rough would be my outline.

That the Chief Sanitary Officer should report direct to the supreme
authority: that the present scheme for the sanitation of the Zone should be acted
upon by this supreme authority and that in considering these matters the supreme
authority should have some person of special knowledge in these matters with whom
he could consult. If the supreme authority were the Secretary of War, I should
think he might call upon the Surgeon General of the Army for recommendation; or,
if the supreme authority were the Commission, it might do the same. That such
portions of this scheme as finally seem good should be adopted and the Chief
Sanitary Officer be directed to make a detailed estimate under this scheme for
one year; that for each month he put in an estimate for funds needed for that month
a sufficient length of time ahead for the supreme authority to act upon; that the
sum allowed by the proper authority be placed to the credit of the Disbursing
Officer of the Sanitary Department and disbursed by him, under the orders of the
Chief Sanitary Officer, with just the same safe-guards and regulations as apply
to any other disbursing officer of the Government; that a Construction Officer be
appointed who would be also under the orders of the Chief Sanitary Officer. This
would enable him to get his supplies expeditiously and have his building and
repairing done rapidly, and, if the scheme were not carried out satisfactorily
the Chief Sanitary Officer would alone be responsible and could justly be held
accountable. Of course, if I had some idea of the form of organization
contemplated by the Secretary of War, I could fit in my scheme more in detail and,
if I remain in charge of health matters on the Isthmus I would like very much
to lay my scheme of organization before the Secretary of War in person. I think
my experience both in Cuba and in Panama would enable me to make many suggestions
that would be useful before a final plan is settled upon

Col. W. C. Gorgas
Nueve for Dr. C.A.L.
Reed of Cincinnati, Q.

He was sent to the Canal
Zone to inspect and
report as to the work
of the Sanitary Dept.

His report was a devasta-
ting attack on the
Panama Commission
which caused its
dismissal by the
President.
